snippet: Senior U.S. officials said the anti-American rhetoric of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s re-election campaign could hinder cooperation on pressing issues like Iran’s nuclear program.
abstract: Senior American officials suggest that anti-American rhetoric employed by Prime Min Vladimir V Putin during his re-election campaign will continue to hinder cooperation between the US and Russia on pressing issues like Iran's nuclear program; Obama has so far neither congratulated nor criticized Putin for his victory, electing to use more temperate rhetoric.

byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and STEVEN LEE MYERS
byline.contributor: David M. Herszenhorn reported from Moscow, and Steven Lee Myers from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Senior U.S. officials said the anti-American rhetoric of Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin’s re-election campaign could hinder cooperation on pressing issues like Iran’s nuclear program.

headline.seo: Ties With U.S. Remain Strained After Russian Election
headline.main: Despite Kremlin’s Signals, U.S. Ties Remain Strained After Russian Election
headline.print_headline: Despite Kremlin’s Signals, U.S. Ties Remain Strained After Russian Election
